reviewText: MASCOT PICTURES made serials under its own name from 1926 to 1935. After that, MASCOT and four other lesser "Poverty Row" studios were combined under the REPUBLIC PICTURES banner. THE LONE DEFENDER (1930) was the first full-sound MASCOT serial (1929's "The King of the Kongo" had a partial soundtrack). Rin Tin Tin was under previous contract to WARNER's, but they didn't think animal movies would do well in the sound era- a serious misjudgement in retrospect. THE STORY: A prospector is murdered by a gang. His dog Rinty sees this crime. Knowing the dog might lead them to the prospector's mine, the gang pursues the unfortunate animal. Help comes however from an unlikely source: an undercover government agent. CAST: Rin Tin Tin - Rinty Walter Miller - Marco Roberto (the "Mysterious Figure," Ramon) June Marlowe - Dolores Valdez (prospector's daughter) Josef Swickard - Juan Valdez (prospector) Buzz Barton - Buzz (Ramon's sidekick) Lee Shumway - Amos Harkey ("The Cactus Kid") Julia Bejarano - Maria (the Duea) Lafe McKee - Sheriff Billings CHAPTERS: 1. The Mystery of the Desert 2. The Fugitive 3. Jaws of Peril 4. Trapped 5. Circle of Death 6. Surrounded by Law 7. The Ghost Speaks 8. The Brink of Destruction 9. The Avalanche 10. Fury of the Desert 11. Cornered 12. Vindicated! LONE DEFENDER trivia: Listed at imdb as an "actor," Rin Tin Tin was born in Lorraine, France in 1918. Discovered at a bombed-out shelter during WWI, the lucky pup eventually made it to America, then Hollywood, after being "discovered" at an L.A. dog show by Darryl Zanuck (Rinty amazed crowds there by jumping 13 feet). He made his first movie in 1922, and had a long and successful career. Rin Tin Tin died at age 14 in 1932-- his remains were returned to France. His descendants continue to flourish today. Stuntman Joe Bonomo (son of the creator of "Bonomo's Turkish Taffy) is best remembered as stunt-double for Lon Chaney in "The Hunchback of Notre Dame." Bonomo's precipitous rope-slide in that silent film is quite an amazing feat. In his 50-year film career, Lee Shumway ("The Cactus Kid") appeared in over 400 movies. . THE LIGHTNING WARRIOR is another Rin Tin Tin movie serial.

VCI Entertainment and Mascot Pictures present..."LONE DEFENDER" (1930) (Dolby digitally remastered), a 12 Chapter cliffhanger from an action packed Mascot serial era under director Richard Thorpe, producer Nat Levine, screenplay by William P. Burt, Ben Cohen and Harry L. Fraser, music score by Lee Zahler....cast includes Rin Tin Tin (Rinty), Walter Miller (Ramon),  June Marlowe (Dolores Valdez), Buzz Barton (Buzz)Josef Swickard (Juan Valdez),  Lee Shumway (Amos Halkey), Frank Lanning (Burke), Bob Kortman (Jenkins), Arthur Morrison (Limpy), Lafe [Lafayette] McKee (Sheriff Billings), Boyd Irwin (deputy) . . . . . . . . .our story deals with a miner's dog Rin Tin Tin in an action packed cliffhanger with government agents and our heroine June Marlowe in quest of a  lost mine...who is the "Cactus Kid" and what part does he play in this with mysterious eyes looking through secret panels and from behind corners, and lots of shadowy presence in the corners to keep you twitching in your seat...can Rinty save the day again and bring all the baddies on the Mascot Picture lot to face the hangman's noose. .just remember double thrills, chills, mystery and suspense...hitting the bull's eye with excitement...don't miss a single spine thrilling episode..return next week to this local theater for another episode of action and adventure that will keep you thrilled until the next chapter....there is a great deal of entertainment here for the cliffhanger fans out there...all courtesy of VCI Entertainment, who in my humble opinion is the best there is in restoring early serials and features.

CHAPTER TITLES:

2. The Fugitive

3. Jaws of Peril

5. Circle of Death

6. Surrounded by Law

7. The Ghost Speaks

8. The Brink of Destruction

9. The Avalanche

10. Fury of the Desert

11. Cornered

12. Vindicated!

Great job by VCI Entertainment for releasing "Lone Defender" (1930), the digital transfere with a clean, clear and crisp print...looking forward to more high quality releases from the vintage serial era of the '30s, '40s & '50s...order your copy now from Amazon or VCI Entertainment where there are plenty of copies available on VHS, stay tuned once again for top notch action mixed with deadly adventure from the "King of Serials" VCI...just the way we like 'em

I agree with the reviewer that said the Mill Creek version of this serial  is of poor quality.  Alpha is a little better, but the Grapevine Video DVD version is much better as a picture and is worth a few dollars more to enjoy  Rin Tin Tin Jr. in this early serial.

After attempting to watch the Mill Creek version of "The Lone Defender," a landmark, action-packed 1930 Rin-Tin-Tin serial, I gave up. The reasons being that the Mill Creek version had horrible picture quality and even worse sound. The sound is so muffled that it is almost impossible to understand any of the dialogue.

So I bought the Alpha version and hoped for the best. Well, the "best" is not what I got. The Alpha version of this serial is a little better than the Mill Creek version, but not much. The picture is a little clearer and the sound is better for the most part. The dialogue in the Alpha version is usually submerged in a sea of hiss, but most of it can be understood without too much of a strain.

So when it comes to grading these two DVD versions, I would have to give Mill Creek an "F" and Alpha a "D+."

This is too bad considering that "The Lone Defender" is the first all-talking serial in film history. And it stars the original Rin-Tin-Tin only two years before his death. Rinty was quite an actor... much better than some of his human counterparts. And the beautiful June Marlowe (who played Miss Crabtree in a few of the early Our Gang talkies) also makes this serial worth the price of admission.

I hope that there is a company somewhere that will give this wonderful serial the star treatment it deserves for a future DVD release.
I was disappointed in this dvd.  The picture and sound quality was terrible.  I was really looking forward to going back to my youth with this program.  Sorry, but did not fit the bill.
June Marlow went on to "star" in the Our Gang Comedies as Miss Crabtree!  Also did a Laurel and Hardy (Pardon Us) Feature
